content:
Hi @WG-traits
Meeting in 10 minutes.
Today is apparently the end of the sprint, so we should discuss that :)
ah right, timezone shenanigans, an hour earlier for just one week
And also we can discuss ReErased and ReEmpty in Chalk
Oh, time changed?
times are a'changing
that sprint went by fast
Indeed
There wasn't a ton of activity
(at least compared to the last couple)
Sprint doc: https://hackmd.io/s1MfBn4bRjyir-aqHZzbKQ
Meeting agenda/log: https://hackmd.io/nrhN5A8sR2eY9UdfJTKcJg?both
We/I haven't been doing a good job at keeping these up to date
no we haven't
Ok @WG-traits
Meeting time
So, announcements to start?
So, big refactoring happened to Chalk this week
And now Chalk more closely matches rustc
i.e. TyData -> TyKind and TypeName has been merged into TyKind
Woah
I didn't even notice that go by :)
hehe
Well, we did some reviewing on the Variance + Generalizer PR
That too :)
which is looking really good modulo those points that were raised
I pushed the lifetime variance fix
and renamed
I was a bit surprised that more tests didn't have to be updated
Need to reply to your comment on the deepnormalizer
but maybe I didn't see all the diffs
So
By default, struct and fn def params are still Invariant
So nothing should change
Updating rustc for the latest chalk version is going to be fun
simplifying the mapping, you mean?
@nikomatsakis can you take a quick look at chalk#633 when you get a chance
yep
@detrumi yes
so I think the focus for the next sprint ought to be the type library
I'm working on some fixes to the integration so might update chalk at the same time.

nikomatsakis said:

so I think the focus for the next sprint ought to be the type library

I agree
and I'm wondering if it'd be useful to allocate some group time (maybe with Zoom) to try and sketch a plan
I feel like clearly i'm not going to do it async ;)
haha, I can be available for sync discussion
I note that @lcnr's changes to make TypeFoldable methods take ownership are relevant too
yes
Wait, did I miss that
All I saw was Lift taking self
Oh, #78313
Oh I did see this but it didn't register in my mind
But yes, I definitely think next sprint should be towards the type library
The biggest hurdle I think at this point might be Param
should we do the sync meeting before actually starting the sprint?
yeah
we should try to make some plans I think
I wonder if the right thing is to solve the hard problems
or to work on the easy ones
I kind of think the latter ;)
We could also potentially just dedicate next week's meeting as the sync meeting
i.e., trying to align folding, visiting, and types
but not maybe resolving the challenges around binders
I definitely think we can start with the easy ones
I guess by Param you mean the way the compiler uses it for two roles?
I feel like we need to get some wins:)
or maybe tht's just me
By Param, I just mean it's existence in rustc but not Chalk
yeah

I think that even if we can't actually share a type library yet (until maybe the binders and Param, and placeholder canonicalization is done), we can definitely split out what will be the shared type library into a separate crate from rustc_middle
I imagine that we can work towards a point where there will eventually be a PR that deletes that crate and it's uses are replaces by chalk-ir (or it just becomes used by Chalk)
yeah
that's kind of what I was imagining
ah, interesting
There might be things we'll run into when moving things out of rustc_middle
was thinking it would become used by Chalk, but the other way around sounds better
I imagine we will start running into problems like immediately :)
yeah probably
So, that'll be some fun refactorings
Anyways, let's postpone this discussion until dedicated meeting
And let's go over the current sprint
So, to start, we had planned a couple design meetings:

• Placeholder canonicalization
    • Current status/recap
    • Canonical vs. instantiated program clauses
  • Removing Param in rustc
    • How is it used currently?
    • Prior work/experimenting?
    • Removal steps?
    • Alternatives? Adding to Chalk?
  • Const evaluation
    • Open PR
    • TooGeneric vs EvaluationError
  • What does it mean to be WellFormed
Oh bad formatting
I think we somewhat got through each of them
yeah, somewhat
It's probably worth at least summarizing the things we talked about and adding it to the wg-traits repo
(side note, so behind on minutes)
maybe just links to the meeting notes
might suffice
So
I definitely want to do that
But 1) meeting notes haven't really been updated well
well, that's it
sorry
I meant links to the zulip topics
i.e., on zulip-archive.rust-lang.org
Ah, so
I feel like there's helpfulness in creating a summary
I do too, I'm just thinking that it's a big investment in time
and having at least links for folks to click may be much easier
and still has value
so people (including our future selves) don't have to read through the entire meeting discussion
also for us to click later
But yeah, I think it's kind of a heavy investment in time
That I don't really have
And haven't really have volunteers
So, at the very least, I will update wg-traits with links to the meetings
so I'm skimming old topics
Anyways, let's continue sprint discussion
it looks like there is work on adding TypeFlags
Haha yes
So, one of the things we discussed for current sprint was shared type library
So, maybe we should recap what all we did do
(sorry, one sec, brb)
Ok back, sorry, work
ok well
So, I think kind -> kind() was this sprint
yeah
and we explored kind -> data but wound up renaming things in chalk instead
obviously, the big Chalk refactoring
and we're working towards introducing type flags
Let me pull up the wg-traits issue and update that...
(rust-lang/wg-traits#16)
so we mainly focused on handling the type variants so far, and less on lifetimes etc.
Hmm, is now a good time to discuss ReErased and ReEmpty?
sure, why not
remind me what those are?

Experiment with removing Apply and TypeName and inlining those as distinct variants in chalk's type

er, sorry
I meant to say
I think we can check this off :)
(and I did so)

Jack Huey said:

Hmm, is now a good time to discuss ReErased and ReEmpty?

so... ReErased is used by the compiler late in compilation
it indicates a region that is not known
In regards to ReErased, I had a thought
ReEmpty is used, I think, primarily in the older "lexical region inference", which I guess we haven't fully removed yet
it's kind of the opposite of "static"
And the answer is probably a no because of perf
if "static" means "data that lives forever", "empty" means "data that is never valid"
But for the bit of compilation that needs erased regions, should those use a different region enum

nikomatsakis said:

if "static" means "data that lives forever", "empty" means "data that is never valid"

so it's valid as long as it's not used?
er, nvm, that's confusingly worded by me
a different enum doesn't sound too bad for performance?

Jack Huey said:

But for the bit of compilation that needs erased regions, should those use a different region enum

yeah, it's probably not practical
in principle we could do it with a distinct Interners or something
(maybe)
well, two different bits: 1) There's a complexity overhead of having a different enum for one bit of compilation and 2) they have to be translated at some point, whereas now it's free
right
also
memory use
Would it ever be possible to remove ReErased
in particular
for types that do not have regions
you don't want to have to re-intern them
but they don't have the same type in all the phases
Being able to erase regions to improve caching is probably too useful to remove.
yeah I think we just have to live with it, but it shouldn't add that much complexity really
Hmm
Okay, so for ReErased, if we add it to Chalk
Do we just panic if we ever see it?
Or should we try to handle it
Handle it. It shouldn't be much more special than 'static, and that I don't remember that being a large diff
I guess, same question for ReEmpty if we need to add it
Yeah, 'static was small and easy
So, can someone who knows how ReErased should behave make a PR?
@nikomatsakis disappeared :O
Sure, create an issue and assign it to me.
Nice. And ReEmpty?
I may as well do both together.
chalk#637
Sure
I've definitely started to get into the mindset of "I want to get things working, and if that means adding things to Chalk that might not be needed in a perfect world, so be it"
I think that's about it for the shared type library last sprint, let's move onto the next point?
rust-analyzer
right, so
When we talked about this last time, there wasn't anything
Anything now?
I was planning on adding type aliases, so r-a can show the types that users typed better
haven't finished it yet, I really should
Nice
I don't think Generator support has been added either
hm, wasn't there a PR in chalk at some point? or do you mean in rust-analyzer?
In rust-analyzer
But I don't think that's there's anything we need to do for rust-analyzer
So let's move on
there's one thing I'd like to do at some point
we added the ability to print chalk programs from rust-analyzer debug output
usable from the analysis-stats infra
right
I'd like to extend that at some point to gather all those programs, so we can test re-entering them in Chalk or something
Ah, that would be nice
Anyways, let's move on. A bit low on time
MVP of rustc-integration
So, I guess under this item we can put the updates in rustc for Chalk
And also some of the test triage we did
But that was a couple weeks ago
the very last point, auto traits for builtin types, was also related to this, because it's causing a lot of test failures
I'd like to take another look after we upgrade for this week's chalk
Hmm, what builtin types did we add this sprint?
Was it just Generator (or was that before this sprint)
Also included in that is auto traits
ah, maybe that was last sprint, yeah
(for builtin types)
There's a couple builtin types left without auto trait support
OpaqueTypes
and AssociatedTypes
I thought opaque types did support auto traits.
I don't remember. @detrumi ?
should be there
(It's unimplemented here)
There are some issues, which I'm working on a fix for, but it at least somewhat works.
That should be unreachable I think...
But I don't actually remember what TyKind::OpaqueType is instead of AliasTy::Opaque
So, it definitely is reachable. rust-analyzer had a ton of issues
I'm not sure we need both of those, actually
there was a reason we did it that way, but the design slightly changed so it might not be needed anymore
The TyKind::AssociatedType branch might be unreachable
It's the same difference as with AliasTy::Projection and TyKind::AssociatedType
Is it?
I'm not sure when we would return that though
Looks pretty unreachable to me: https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/blob/ea532e03adfeb7fa6cc68881a1205a2f3d2b1933/chalk-solve/src/clauses.rs#L188
oh fun, it says unimplemented for opaque/associated there as well
Only because I added the empty arms so that rust-analyzer stopped crashing
That's correct, they're handled elsewhere.
ah, then that should actually be unreachable!()?
But that handling should maybe be moved there.
or update the comment, idk
I guess you're talking about https://github.com/rust-lang/chalk/blob/ea532e03adfeb7fa6cc68881a1205a2f3d2b1933/chalk-solve/src/clauses.rs#L212
but that still doesn't cover TyKind::OpaqueTy
only the TyKind::Alias variant
Yes, that's a bug I'm fixing
Oh okay
Okay, so, let's move on from this for now
3 minutes left
Adding Subtyping and Variance to Chalk
The PR is really close
'nuff said :P
Refactor rustcâ€™s Binder to track bound vars
I've been slowly chipping away at this in my branch
But would maybe like to discuss with @nikomatsakis in sync a bit
at some point
Make builtin Chalk types implements auto traits
when he stops disappearing :stuck_out_tongue:
which we talked about
yep
Anyways, I think we should either plan to have a sync meeting about type library some time this week
Or just plan to make next meeting that
(maybe do zoom)
And we can call that "sprint planning"
We can do one more sprint this year. And then take whatever time left at the end of the year for break
hm, not sure about doing that at the next meeting time
probably less people participate in the zoom call, and for sprint planning it's useful to have people chime in with what they want to work on
Yeah, I know @nikomatsakis has been trying to set up some Chalk time on Fridays, so maybe then
(sorry sorry, I got pulled away ..)

Jack Huey said:

Refactor rustcâ€™s Binder to track bound vars

that's something I am quite interested in, so if you ever need another opinion or pair of eyes here please notify me

nikomatsakis said:

(sorry sorry, I got pulled away ..)

@nikomatsakis when is good for a sync meeting for you
@Jack Huey good question
it'd have to be this coming friday or next monday I think
If both work for you, maybe create a poll and whoever is interested in joining can vote based on availability
@nikomatsakis see above
